body.p: The purpose of this activity is to show you how to solve word problems involving the normal distribution. Most statistical software packages, much like the normal table, are set up to give answers to problems involving "less than." This means that the software does the "finding z-scores and looking up the table" work for us, but we still need to make sure that we pose the question in terms of "less than," and/or, if needed, adjust the answer that the software gives us.
Recall that we have two types of problems that are of interest: finding probabilities given values, and finding values given probabilities. Below are the instructions for both types.
To illustrate this we'll use an example from a previous activity: Finding P(X > 700) where X is the SAT-M score which has a normal distribution with a mean of 507 and standard deviation of 111.

ul.li: Open StatCrunch.
Choose Stat → Calculators → Normal.
Enter the mean and standard deviation, which in this case are 507 and 111.
Select the appropriate symbol, which in this case is "= >." (Note that for continuous random variables > and ≥ have equivalent probabilities.)
Enter the normal value x, which in this case is 700.
Click on Compute

alternative.title: Minitab Instructions

ul.li: Open Minitab with a new worksheet.
Choose Calc → Probability distributions → Normal.
Select the Cumulative probability button.
Enter the mean and standard deviation of your normal distribution (in this case, 507 and 111).
Select "Input constant," and next to it enter the normal value x (in this case 700).
click OK.

alternative.title: Excel 2007 Instructions

ul.li: Open Excel with a new worksheet.
First, we'll create a table with the given values:
To create this table, first make the row and column labels: pick a cell and type Statistic. Then move one cell to the right and type Value.
Now, in the cell underneath Statistic, type Population Mean. In the cell to the right of that, enter the population mean (in this case, 507).
Similarly, enter values for Population Standard Deviation and X.
Now we'll add two new statistics to the table we created: z-score and P(X = 700) and calculate their values.
To calculate the z-score, we'll use the equation z = (X − mean)/stdev. In this case, we get z = (700 − 507)/111, or 1.738739.

To calculate P(X = 700), we'll use an Excel function called NORMSDIST, which takes a z-score and uses it to calculate a probability. This step takes the place of our having to look up the probability in a normal table. In the cell next to P(X = 700), type =NORMSDIST(1.738739). Excel tells us that the probability is 0.95896.

alternative.p: We need to take it from here and remember that P(X > 700) is then 1 − 0.95896 = 0.04104. Note that when we solved this problem using the table in an earlier activity we rounded z-scores and therefore our answer was slightly different, but very close (0.0409).
Similarly, if we wanted to find P(400 < X < 600) we would need to do two separate calculations; one for P(X < 600), and one for P(X < 400), and subtract.

alternative.title: TI Instructions

ul.li: Choose DISTR (2ND/VARS).
Select 2:normalcdf(.
The normal cumulative distribution function requires the following parameters: normalcdf(lower limit, upper limit, mean, standard deviation).
Note: If you omit mean and standard deviation, the defaults are mean = 0 and standard deviation = 1.

You need to enter a lower limit and upper limit for the region of the normal curve that you’re interested in. In this case, there is only a lower limit of 700. So, we’re really interested in (700, ∞).
Next to lower: type in 700.

The TI doesn’t represent infinity directly, so we’ll use 1*10^99 as the upper bound. You get this value on the TI as 1E99. Next to upper: press 1, then EE (2ND/, that’s a comma, which is the button above the 7 button). Then press 99.
Next to µ type in the mean of your normal distribution (in this case, 507).
Next to σ type in the standard deviation of your normal distribution (in this case, 111).
Use the down arrow to highlight Paste and press ENTER
You should see: normalcdf(700,1E99,507,111).
Press ENTER.

body.p: As mentioned before, is set up to find a value x that satisfies P(X < x) = some given probability. To illustrate, we use an example from a previous activity: finding the value of x that satisfies P(X > x) = 0.02 where X is the SAT-M score, which has a normal distribution with a mean of 507 and standard deviation of 111. Before we start, it will be useful to rephrase the problem in terms of X < x; we are looking for the value of x that satisfies P(X < x) = 0.98.

alternative.title: Excel 2007 Instructions

ul.li: To do this in Excel, we can use a table similar to the one we created above, but this time we're looking for: z-score and X. Basically, we're going to do the inverse of the procedure we described above.

This time, we're given the population mean and standard deviation, but instead of being given an X and asked to find the probability, we're given a probability and asked to find the corresponding X value.

To calculate the z-score given a probability, we'll use another Excel function called NORMSINV, that takes a probability and uses it to calculate a z-score. This function is the inverse of the NORMSDIST function that we used previously, and takes the place of us having to look up the z-score in a normal table. The formula we'll use is =NORMSINV(0.98). Excel tells us that the z-score is 2.053748.
To calculate the X value that corresponds to that z-score, we'll again use the equation z = (X - mean)/stdev. In this case, we get X = 2.053748 * 111 + 507, or 734.966.

alternative.p: Excel tells us that the value that we are looking for (the 98th percentile) is 734.966. Our solution in the previous activity using the table gave us the answer 734.55 due to rounding.
Now use Excel to work through the following exercise:
